5.title: Spatial Phone for Meta Quest 3 mirrors your smartphone into the VR headset
5.snippet: Spatial Phone brings your phone apps to virtual reality. Getting started is tricky, but the payoff might be worth it.
5.content:
Spatial Phone for Meta Quest 3 mirrors your smartphone into the VR headset

Image: butter chicken pizza

Der Artikel kann nur mit aktiviertem JavaScript dargestellt werden. Bitte aktiviere JavaScript in deinem Browser und lade die Seite neu.

From YouTube to WhatsApp: Spatial Phone brings your phone apps to virtual reality. Getting started is tricky, but the payoff might be worth it.

Ad

Ad

The new “Spatial Phone: Mirror & Control” app lets you view and control your Android phone's screen directly in your VR headset. Whether you want to check WhatsApp messages in mixed reality or stream YouTube music during a game of Eleven Table Tennis, it's now possible without removing your headset.

Created by solo developer “butter chicken pizza,” this practical solution aims to keep you immersed in VR. Here's how it performs in real-world testing.

Note: Spatial Phone currently works only with Android 8 and newer devices, with an iPhone version coming soon. The app costs $5.

Entry hurdle: Companion app

Getting the app up and running takes some effort. You'll need to install a companion app on your phone through Google Play. While Spatial Phone opens the Quest browser to help you find it, the Google login process has issues, and finding the app directly in the Play Store on my Smartphone didn't work either.

Ad

Ad

The hand-tracking controls work just as precisely in Spatial Phone as they do in the Quest menu. | Picture: butter chicken pizzaI found a workaround by sending myself the Play Store link through WhatsApp for Meta Quest. It's not the smoothest process, but it gets the job done. The real frustration comes from the pairing process.

To connect your headset and phone, you need to enter a ten-digit code mixing numbers with upper and lowercase letters. Typing in passwords in VR is already tedious, but distinguishing between similar characters like the letter O and the number 0, or capital I and lowercase l, makes it even more challenging. The developer has acknowledged this issue on Discord and plans to streamline the process in a future update.

I'm in!

Once you clear these initial hurdles, your phone screen appears as a window in your VR environment within seconds. Before you can control your phone using Quest controllers or hand tracking, you'll need to enable an accessibility setting on your Android device. The app helpfully guides you to the right menu with a single tap.

The control scheme works smoothly — whether using hand tracking or VR controllers, I could easily navigate between screens, scroll through websites, and play YouTube videos without touching my phone.

Ad

Ad

However, some limitations exist. The app stops working if your phone screen goes to sleep, requiring both the companion app and phone display to stay active. You also need to repeat the pairing process and enter that lengthy code every time you launch the VR app.

Testing with a Samsung Galaxy S24 revealed some issues — occasional black screens, frozen images, and problems with audio transfer to the headset. While apps like YouTube, WhatsApp, and web browsers display clearly in VR, mirroring the Netflix app on Quest 3 currently doesn't work.

My verdict on Spatial Phone: Exciting app with room for improvement

Despite its rough edges, Spatial Phone shows promise. The image quality is sharp, and the frame rate is generally smooth, with only occasional stuttering. Once configured, the controls feel precise and responsive.

Technical issues vary by phone model, ranging from connection issues to app crashes. The required re-pairing at each launch currently makes it less convenient than simply switching to mixed reality for a quick phone check.

Ad

Ad

However, given the developer's active community engagement and frequent updates, this affordable tool could soon become essential for Quest users wanting seamless phone access in VR. The foundation is solid — it just needs some polishing to reach its full potential.

6.title: Let’s axe Meta’s fact-checkers
6.snippet: Implementing user-generated community notes will democratize fact-checking, and rid the app of a tool which has long become synonymous with big tech's...
6.content:
On Jan. 20, President Donald Trump made his grand return to the Oval Office with his second presidential inauguration. While the 47th president rattled on about renaming the Gulf of Mexico and Mount Denali, many viewers of the event scanned the background and focused on the long list of billionaires poking their heads out throughout the Capitol rotunda. However, out of all the billionaires and personalities, none stood out quite as much as Meta CEO and billionaire Mark Zuckerberg.

Since Trump’s victory last November, the Meta CEO has undergone a complete transformation. Once a scrawny, self-proclaimed “nerd,” Zuckerberg has rebranded himself, seemingly in an attempt to appease Trump after years of threats and accusations. This “Zuck 2.0” has reversed many of the initiatives that had once made him one of the president’s biggest enemies. Among them is the end of Meta’s fact-checking system, a program which contracted third parties to annotate or remove content they deem to be false or lacking in context. Instead, Zuckerberg announced that Meta will employ a system similar to the one used by his rival turned fellow technocrat: Elon Musk. After his purchase of Twitter in 2022, Musk rolled out Community Notes on the app and now — two years and an election later — Zuckerberg is following suit.

Many Meta users criticized the decision, claiming that this critical function mitigates the spread of misinformation and encourages accountability online. While there is some merit to these critiques — as misinformation has long been an issue on social media — after years of implementation, fact-checking has done little to reduce the overwhelming amount of fake news that plagues Meta’s platforms. Implementing user-generated Community Notes will democratize fact-checking and rid the app of a tool that has long become synonymous with big tech’s arrogance and self-righteousness with regards to politics.

Ever since fact-checking became widespread online, people have raised concerns about the efficacy and impartiality of the practice. In fact, many — including Zuckerberg himself — have claimed that the tool has shown to be “too politically biased,” oftentimes showing partiality to left-leaning concepts or ideals.

In 2019, one of Facebook’s sanctioned fact-checkers, Checkyourfact, came under fire for failing to fact-check content questioning the effects of climate change. It was later revealed that the site was founded as an offshoot of Tucker Carlson’s “The Daily Caller,” a right-wing news site famous for pushing conspiracies and inflammatory headlines. While many expected Facebook to remove the company’s credentials after the incident, Meta never addressed the allegations and the site still remains as one of Facebook’s sanctioned fact-checkers to this day.

The partisan slant found in fact-checking has manifested itself in more ways than just biased reporting. Many have accused fact-checkers of selectively assessing claims, being more likely to fact-check conservative authors and politicians rather than liberal ones. These claims are not unfounded, and many have taken to social media to criticize fact-checkers for missing some glaringly misleading comments.

Fact-checking alone is not robust enough to mitigate the many fake articles and stories that plague each of Meta’s platforms. Meta only employs 10 U.S.-based fact-checking organizations, who are tasked with vetting one billion stories posted every day across all platforms. There is no realistic way for a system relying on for-profit companies to assess such vast amounts of content. Instead, Community Notes offer a more realistic alternative by individually certifying users, this ensures that more stories are checked and certified.

In Meta’s original system, fact-checks are conducted by a small selection of companies approved by Meta. This is different from the Community Notes system, where users interested in participating are individually vetted and are allowed to give anonymous context to stories that might be misleading or false.

Community Notes decentralizes the fact-checking process, allowing users to directly participate, encouraging a culture of grassroots participation rather than 10 single organizations fact-checking. While critics argue that the function can lead to unchecked behavior, this issue isn’t unique to Community Notes: The same could be said for the various fact-checking organizations that work behind the scenes, away from the purview of the people and impervious to any public criticism.

As the transition into Community Notes begins, it could serve as a great opportunity to remind users to do their own research and verify information with reputable sources. Ever since the internet’s inception, people have been taught to be cautious, especially in regard to trusting what they read online. Rather than relying on other users or companies, it might be good to be your own fact-checker.

As Zuckerberg unveils this new persona, it is important for the public to question the decisions and changes that come with it, especially as they relate to misinformation and politics across his platforms. However, gutting fact-checking on his platforms is a step toward a more transparent and community-minded culture across Meta. After years of being implemented across Meta’s platforms, various controversies and no sign of correction has proven that fact-checking isn’t the answer to social media’s fake news crisis. Instead, Community Notes will serve as an opportunity to allow the public to engage directly with fact-checking, and do so on a wider scale.

Mateo Alvarez is an Opinion columnist studying political science. His column, “Byte the Ballot,” discusses the ways in which politics tangle with digital culture. He can be reached at mateoalv@umich.edu.

7.title: Mesa College Promise expands scholarship opportunities thanks to Meta
7.snippet: Mesa Community College has announced they have been granted $225000 through Meta that will provide more scholarship opportunities.
7.content:
PHOENIX — Mesa Community College has announced that its Mesa College Promise program has been granted $225,000 through Meta that will provide more scholarship opportunities to students, according to a news release.

The contribution will help students pursuing STEM certificates and degrees with tuition costs and fees.

“Meta’s generous contribution supports Mesa College Promise’s vital role in connecting Mesa residents with pathways to higher education and better job prospects,” MCC President Dr. Richard Daniel said during Meta’s Mesa Data Center grand opening celebration on Thursday.

“Promise’s recent expansion from high school to include adult learners accelerates building the workforce of tomorrow.”

The grant brings Meta’s total contribution to the Mesa College Promise to $300,000.

“We are proud to be active members of the Mesa community, which includes investing in local organizations that have a positive impact,” Manager for Meta’s Mesa Data Center David Williams said.

“Mesa Community College and the Mesa College Promise program provide tremendous support for residents looking to further their education, and we’re excited to see this next wave of STEM advancement in the East Valley.”

What is the Mesa College Promise?

The Mesa College Promise is a partnership between Mesa and MCC that provides financial support to students who have not received enough federal student aid (FAFSA) funds or other scholarships to cover tuition costs.

0.title: I just used a Meta Quest VR headset to get 3 virtual monitors on a Windows 11 PC — and I was blown away
0.snippet: Microsoft's Mixed Reality Link app lets you connect your Meta Quest VR headset to a Windows 11 PC, offering three virtual monitors, and I've been thoroughly...
0.content:
Ever since hearing about Microsoft's Mixed Reality Link app that allows Meta Quest VR headsets to connect to a Windows 11 PC, I've been stoked about trying it out. I mean, being able to see three virtual monitors in mixed reality? That's a big ol' upgrade to my PC setup.

I've been burned by Meta in the past, though. From trying to play PCVR via the Quest 2 but never managing to get a decent connection on my gaming laptop to trying to set up work meetings in the Metaverse (I wouldn't recommend that), using Meta's VR headset for anything other than gaming was a struggle.

But that changed with the Meta Quest 3. With its mixed-reality capabilities, faster Snapdragon XR2 Gen 2 processor and smoother visuals, this headset paved the way for Meta to deliver more worthwhile experiences. Even better, the Quest 3S made it all more accessible to consumers.

Case and point: Meta Quest VR headsets linking up to a Windows 11 PC. I finally tried out the Mixed Reality Link app and couldn't believe how easy it was to expand my PC setup with three huge virtual displays that I could move and resize at will — all with a wireless connection to a Quest 3.

There are still some quirks to iron out (the app is still in preview), but anyone with a Quest 3 or Quest 3S and a Windows 11 PC should give this new feature a whirl.

A (semi) easy setup

(Image credit: Future / Tom's Guide)

Since the Mixed Reality Link app is still in preview, setting up the link with a Meta Quest 3 or 3S headset to a Windows 11 PC may not be as straightforward. As an example, when following the steps to get it working via Meta's support page, I found it fell short in a couple of steps.

For one, when it states that I should see a "prompt to pair your PC" above my keyboard, there was none in sight. Secondly, when told to scan the QR code on my laptop's display using my Meta Quest 3 to pair the device via the Mixed Reality Link app, the headset wouldn't recognize it (although this is apparently still an experimental "Advanced" feature on the Quest).

Luckily, this was quickly remedied with another step noted in the setup guide. Simply pair the device by opening Quick Settings (the clock on the universal menu) on the Quest, selecting Remote Desktop and then Add new device.

From there, I followed the prompts to connect the Quest to my Windows 11 PC and Huzzah! I was up and running. Even better, I was greeted by a massive virtual screen of my PC.

You can give this a whirl yourself if you meet the following requirements:

Have a Meta Quest 3 or Meta Quest 3S headset

Use Windows 11 (22H2 or newer) on your PC

Run Horizon OS v72 or newer on your headset

Be on the same Wi-Fi network on your PC and Quest headset (5Ghz or 6Ghz)

Have at least a Radeon RX 5000 series, GTX 1000 or Ryzen 3000 series GPU or newer

For more, check out Microsoft's requirements. To note, you'll need to switch on the Pair to PC with Mixed Reality Link feature in Advanced settings on your Meta Quest in order for this to work.

3 virtual monitors at your whim

(Image credit: Future / Tom's Guide)

Remember Tank in "The Matrix" sitting in front of an array of stacked displays? Well, I didn't. I completely forgot about him until now, but that's who I felt like once I had full control of the virtual monitors available on the Quest 3.

Despite having a full-blown display that could have easily measured over 50 inches right in front of my eyes, the first thing I noticed was the lack of lag. Latency felt virtually seamless even with a wireless connection; I moved my cursor and it reacted immediately on my headset's virtual monitor.

Quite honestly, this caught me off guard, as I thought, "wait, I can actually really use this." Not to say that I went in thinking the feature would be a dud, but I didn't think I would want to use it on a regular basis.

Using the Quest's Touch plus controller or just my hands via hand-tracking (which can be sketchy at times), I was able to move the virtual display wherever I wanted: right up to my face, far off in the distance, to the side, over my head; anywhere.

(Image credit: Future / Tom's Guide)

What made this better was being able to easily resize the screen to whatever I saw fit. It could be a super-sized 16:9 display, a vertical-type monitor for scrolling, more of an ultra-wide look and more. That said, this could only go so far, as my gaming laptop's display couldn't mimic these differently sized monitor sizes.

Then I added the other virtual monitors. This was as simple as selecting that "add" option at the bottom right corner of the Quest headset. A total of three virtual monitors can be used at once, and you can mix and match how they're placed. All spaced horizontally? Sure. Stacked vertically? No problem. Spaced in an L shape so I could see them all at once? You know it.

(Image credit: Future / Tom's Guide)

I was scrolling through websites while watching a YouTube video and writing in a document all at once. And if one monitor was too far out of sight, I could easily pick it up and rearrange its placement. I believe this is what Meta should have had in mind when trying to bring the workforce over to virtual reality through the Meta Quest Pro.

Now, this isn't a bad deal for anyone looking for a multi-monitor setup. It sure beats buying three whole displays, even if they are the best monitors around. It's a more affordable way to build upon your PC setup. Of course, it's not without its caveats.

Not a complete game-changer

While it's a blast to use my Quest 3 to expand on how I use my laptop, it's unlikely I'd be using this feature as an everyday essential. Especially for work, as Meta is still working out how to get video calls, like in Microsoft Teams, while the connection is active.

More importantly, it isn't as if I don't notice I'm wearing a VR headset while using my PC as I normally would. Meta made strides with the design of the Quest 3, making it more comfortable to wear over longer periods of time. But yes, my face still feels like it's been pressed against after an hour or two, and the imprints are evidence.

(Image credit: Future / Tom's Guide)

Then there's the battery. Unless you're using one of the best Quest 3 accessories, such as the Elite Strap with battery, you'll only get about two hours of juice before the headset needs a charge. A wireless connection is great and all, but my Quest 3 will need to be plugged in if I were to use it for extended sessions on my laptop.

Finally, the VR headset's full-color passthrough isn't quite sharp enough for me to see my keyboard. I know, not everyone needs to actually see their keyboard while typing, but I'm the kind of typist who has a gander every once in a while to find specific keys. Quest's pass-through to the real world doesn't make that easy, especially in low-light settings.

In the grand scheme of what the Mixed Reality Link app offers, these are only minor snags. But with rumors of a Meta Quest 4 swirling, another VR headset down the line could fix these issues, and dare I say, bring even more virtual monitors. In the meantime, though, there's another way this feature came in handy.

Large-screen gaming

(Image credit: Future / Tom's Guide)

Anything I do on my laptop will be seen through the virtual monitors on my Quest 3. So, I decided to give my PC games the real big-screen treatment and booted up Steam and Xbox Game Pass — and it was a mixed treat.

I first tried Indiana Jones and the Great Circle, and everything looked on point. With the gorgeous graphics my RTX 3080-equipped laptop could push out, I was thrilled seeing the lush landscapes of the Vatican City over a moonlit sky on a massive virtual display. However, I noticed slight stutters when moving around, despite my inputs registering near-instantly. It may be because my laptop can't keep up with the connectivity, but it's still not the ideal way to play.

(Image credit: Future / Tom's Guide)

While not unplayable, I wondered if a less demanding game would fare better. I started playing Carrion, the pixel-like horror game where you play a "The Thing"-type monster, and had a far better time. Gameplay was smooth, and I enjoyed having a large screen to cruelly crawl around stalking unsuspecting scientists.

The link was better at offering solid streams of games that didn't require intense processing power, for me at least. Still, will I continue to play such games through a Quest 3 headset? You better believe it.

Final thoughts

There are other apps on the Meta Store that let you use your PC as a remote display, such as the popular Virtual Desktop app. But that costs $24/£18, and with Microsoft's Mixed Reality Link, it's free. It's a major step in the company's push to make its VR headsets more than just a gaming outlet for many, even if it still has a few faults in the tank.

Still, I'll be using my Quest 3 with a PC far more often thanks to the Mixed Reality Link app, and once it's fully out of preview, it will be far more viable. Plus, who wouldn't want adjustable monitors for a more affordable price? While using a VR headset for general tasks on my laptop is still far away, it's much closer than I think it is — even if I'll mainly use it for big-screen gaming.

If you're looking to see how virtual reality has progressed yourself, try out one of the best VR headsets (spolier: you'll want the Meta Quest 3).

1.title: Delaware tech exodus includes Meta, eyeing Texas in big move
1.snippet: Meta is considering reincorporating in Texas, joining other companies like Tesla and SpaceX in moving from Delaware.
1.content:
A photograph taken during the World Economic Forum (WEF) annual meeting in Davos on January 18, 2024, shows the logo of Meta. FABRICE COFFRINI/AFP via Getty Images

Meta might be the next social media giant to call Texas home in some regard. The Wall Street Journal reported the news on Friday, January 31, that company leaders have spoken to state officials about the possible reincorporation from Delaware.

Meta may possibly choose to reincorporate in another state, the report says, and the company has "no plans to move the company’s corporate headquarters from California." Meta is the parent company that operates major social media platforms like Facebook, Instagram and the growing X-competitor Threads.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

Texas is home to a number of Meta operations, including the recent announcement to move content moderators from California to Texas, along with Meta data centers in Dallas and Temple.

In February 2024, Elon Musk urged Tesla shareholders to reincorporate from Delware to Texas in a similar move prompted by a court decision over a roughly $56 billion compensation package. The company officially reincorporated in Texas in June.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

On Friday, cloud storage company DropBox also reportedly announced it would be reincorporating to Nevada from Delaware.

MySA has reached out to Meta for more information.

Why do business incorporate in Delaware?

The second-smallest state in the U.S. by area is also the state with the highest number of incorporations — the state boasts more than 1,000,000 businesses and reports its home to more than 66% of the Fortune 500 companies.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

The state says it "has been preeminent as the place for businesses to incorporate since the early 1900s, and its incorporation business, supplemented by the growth in numbers of such 'alternative entities' as limited liability companies, limited partnerships and statutory trusts, continues to grow smartly."

2.title: Meta’s Subscription Strategy Gains Momentum as Alternative Revenue Streams Take Shape
2.snippet: Meta's 2024 earnings report highlights strong revenue growth, but its focus on subscriptions—via Reality Labs, WhatsApp Business, and AI-powered...
2.content:
Meta’s Subscription: A Strategic Shift Beyond Ads

Meta Platforms, Inc. (Nasdaq: META) reported $48.39 billion in Q4 2024 revenue, a 21% increase year-over-year. For the full year, revenue climbed 22% to $164.5 billion. While advertising remains Meta’s core business, CEO Mark Zuckerberg and CFO Susan Li emphasized long-term investments in subscription-based models, monetized AI services, and alternative revenue streams.

Reality Labs: Meta’s VR and AR division posted $2.15 billion in 2024 revenue , up from $1.9 billion in 2023 . However, it remains a costly bet , with a $17.73 billion operating loss for the year . Zuckerberg called 2025 a pivotal year, saying, “This will be the year when we understand the trajectory for AI glasses as a category.” This suggests a push for VR/AR subscription models and monetized digital experiences.





Meta’s VR and AR division posted , up from . However, it remains a , with . Zuckerberg called 2025 a pivotal year, saying, “This will be the year when we understand the trajectory for AI glasses as a category.” This suggests a push for and monetized digital experiences. WhatsApp Business Growth: Meta’s “Other Revenue” grew 55% , largely driven by WhatsApp Business Platform , which offers subscription-like tools for business messaging. This suggests messaging monetization is gaining traction as a non-advertising revenue stream.





Meta’s , largely driven by , which offers tools for business messaging. This suggests as a non-advertising revenue stream. AI-Powered Monetization: Meta AI saw 700 million monthly active users, yet remains in an investment phase rather than immediate monetization. However, Susan Li hinted at future paid models, saying, “There will be pretty clear monetization opportunities, including paid recommendations and a premium offering.”





Regulatory Pressures Fuel Subscription Growth

Meta’s expansion into subscriptions is not just strategic—it’s necessary. Increasing regulatory scrutiny in the EU and U.S. has forced Meta to explore non-advertising revenue streams, including its ad-free subscription tiers in Europe.

Zuckerberg also acknowledged regulatory challenges, noting, “We continue to monitor an active regulatory landscape that could significantly impact our business.” If restrictions on ad targeting intensify, Meta’s subscription models may become a global standard rather than a regional test.

Looking ahead, Meta projects Q1 2025 revenue of $39.5–$41.8 billion (an 8–15% increase YoY), with a growing emphasis on infrastructure, AI, and Reality Labs.





INSIDER TAKE:

Meta’s 2024 earnings highlight a company in transition—one that remains ad-dominant but is aggressively exploring new revenue streams.

Reality Labs losses remain high, but Meta is playing the long game on VR/AR monetization.

WhatsApp Business growth signals subscription potential in messaging and commerce.

AI-powered monetization will take time, but Meta AI could eventually introduce paid features.

Regulatory pressure is a driving force behind Meta’s subscription expansion.

For subscription executives, Meta’s shift reinforces key industry trends:

Diversification is crucial—ad models alone are vulnerable to regulatory risks. AI-driven monetization is emerging, though direct revenue may take years. The subscription economy is expanding beyond media and software—business messaging, digital experiences, and AI tools are the next frontier.

While Meta is not yet a subscription-first company, its 2024 results confirm a growing reliance on alternative revenue streams—something subscription leaders should watch closely.

3.title: Illuminating Indie Games V2: Tense Climbing, Meta Narratives, and More Peaceful Diorama Building
3.snippet: On today's 'Illuminating Indie Games,' I'll be introducing you to challenging mountain climbing and goofy meta experiences!
3.content:
Welcome back to Illuminating Indie Games, where I spotlight underrepresented indie titles I come across during my internet travels. As always, here are the rules. If you see something you like, be sure to add the game to your Steam wishlist. Doing so helps immensely in making these creators’ projects more visible for others to discover! With that out of the way, let’s dive in — starting with an unhinged meta narrative.

first up on illuminating indie games: ‘Do Not Press The Button (Or You’ll Delete The Multiverse)’

Screenshot: Theseus Games

Come on. You’ve likely played The Stanley Parable. You know what this is! Do Not Press the Button is a narrative-minded indie title that’s hoping to mess with you in the best ways imaginable. “A first-person, narrative-driven game featuring The Developer, who questions, taunts, and tests you at every turn. You shouldn’t press the button, but you’ll want to. You will have control, and you will have none. Power is in your hands… or is it?” the game’s Steam page says.

Videos by VICE

You can download and play the “Prologue” demo now (using the above link, of course). If you like games that enjoy riffing on the medium, this one is worth keeping an eye on when it releases in Q1 2025.

Play video

next: ‘block block block’

Screenshot: Aender Lara

Block Block Block is just such a satisfying concept. The premise couldn’t be more suited for the always-relevant cozy genre. “Design your dream space! In this tiny cozy building game, stack and arrange uniquely shaped wooden blocks to craft charming dioramas. Design cozy bakeries, elegant living rooms, or quirky studios. Create beautiful spaces filled with warmth and personality.”

Much to my chagrin, you’re only able to look at trailers of this indie champion. Additionally, the release date/window is currently unknown. But, I’m a simple man. I see a cozy diorama crafting game, I support a cozy diorama crafting game.

and finally: ‘cairn’

Screenshot: The Game Bakers

Now, Cairn is a Dwayne Indie Game (TM) through and through. Remember Don’t Nod’s Jusant (a woefully underrated title I wish more people played)? Well, this isn’t that kind of “cutesy” climbing affair. Cairn is equal parts survival, resource management, and heart-pounding mountain-climbing simulator! If you see it, you can climb it! Just be careful — you’ll need to make sure you have the right gear. Oh, and food, water, and medicine. I told you it would be hardcore!

“Attempt your first ascent with Aava in Tenzen mountain ridge. Climb anywhere and plan your route carefully, managing pitons and resources as you explore the mountain. Hone your skills before the ascent of unforgiving Mount Kami.”

Cairn is also from the wonderfully creative minds at The Game Bakers. They gave us 2020’s Haven and 2016’s Furi. That combined with the demo‘s overwhelmingly positive reception means we’re in good hands when the game (hopefully) fully releases this year!

Play video

that wraps up today’s indie game roundup — now get outta here

Few things are more rewarding than setting aside a space for indie creativity in the games industry! Now more than ever, it’s up to gamers and games media outlets to boost as many “smaller” projects as possible. The AAA bubble may very well burst in the coming years. If it does, we all have to do the work to give indie devs the lift they need to not just survive, but thrive.

4.title: Meta Confirms Zero-Click WhatsApp Spyware Attack Targeting 90 Journalists, Activists
4.snippet: Meta-owned WhatsApp disrupted a zero-click spyware campaign by Paragon Solutions, targeting 90 journalists and activists.
4.content:
Meta-owned WhatsApp on Friday said it disrupted a campaign that involved the use of spyware to target journalists and civil society members.

The campaign, which targeted around 90 members, involved the use of spyware from an Israeli company known as Paragon Solutions. The attackers were neutralized in December 2024.

In a statement to The Guardian, the encrypted messaging app said it has reached out to affected users, stating it had "high confidence" that the users were targeted and "possibly compromised." It's currently not known who is behind the campaign and for how long it took place.

The attack chain is said to be zero-click, meaning the deployment of the spyware occurs without requiring any user interaction. It's suspected to involve the distribution of a specially-crafted PDF file sent to individuals who were added to group chats on WhatsApp.

The company noted the targets were spread across over two dozen countries, including several in Europe, adding it notified the affected parties and provided them information on how to protect themselves.

"This is the latest example of why spyware companies must be held accountable for their unlawful actions," a WhatsApp spokesperson told The Hacker News. "WhatsApp will continue to protect peoples' ability to communicate privately."

The company also revealed that it had sent Paragon a "cease and desist" letter and that it was considering other options. The development marks the first time the company has been linked to cases where its technology has been misused.

Like NSO Group, Paragon is the maker of surveillance software called Graphite that's offered to government clients in order to combat digital threats. It was acquired by a U.S.-based investment group AE Industrial Partners in December in a deal worth $500 million.

On its barebones website, the company claims it provides customers with "ethically based tools" to "disrupt intractable threats," as well as offer "cyber and forensic capabilities to locate and analyze digital data."

In late 2022, it came to light that Graphite was used by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) for counternarcotics operations. Last year, the Center for Democracy and Technology (CDT) called on the Department of Homeland Security to release details about its $2 million contract with Paragon.

News of the campaign comes weeks after a judge in California ruled in WhatsApp's favor in a landmark case against NSO Group for using its infrastructure to deliver the Pegasus spyware to 1,400 devices in May 2019.

Meta's disclosure also coincided with the arrest of former Polish Justice Minister Zbigniew Ziobro over allegations that he sanctioned the use of Pegasus spyware to surveil opposition leaders and oversaw cases where the technology was used.

Update

The Italian government, on February 5, 2025, said the spyware campaign carried out with spyware made by Paragon Solutions, targeted individuals across several countries in Europe. This included seven Italian citizens, it added.

The people targeted own phones with numbers tied to Belgium, Greece, Latvia, Lithuania, Austria, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain and Sweden, per the statement. The government has denied any involvement in the activity.

So far, three identified victims include an Italian investigative journalist, a co-founder of the Mediterranea Saving Humans charity, and a Sweden-based Libyan activist. It's currently not known who is behind the spying campaign.

Earlier this week, Paragon Solutions told TechCrunch that the company counts the U.S. government and its allies as clients, but did not disclose who they were. It also said it licenses its technology to a "select group of global democracies" and that it has "zero-tolerance policy" against illicit use of its tools.

Another Paragon Spyware Target Revealed

Another co-founder of Mediterranea Saving Humans has also come forward as one of the alleged targets of the campaign that leveraged spyware made by Paragon, TechCrunch reported on February 11, 2025.

(The story was updated after publication to include a statement from Meta/WhatsApp.)

5.title: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg Just Shared Great News for Nvidia, Broadcom, and Arista Networks Investors
5.snippet: Meta's artificial intelligence plans will break new ground in 2025.
5.content:
Meta's artificial intelligence plans will break new ground in 2025.

Big tech companies are spending heavily to stay at the forefront of artificial intelligence. Budgets for building AI data centers filled with GPUs and network switches jumped higher in 2024. And a recent update from Meta Platforms (META -4.67%) CEO Mark Zuckerberg says 2025 could see an even bigger jump in spending.

Zuckerberg said in a Facebook post that Meta will spend between $60 billion and $65 billion in capital expenditures in 2025. That's up from $38 billion to $40 billion in 2024, a 60% jump at the midpoint of each forecast. Despite previous comments from Zuckerberg hinting at a big increase in spending for 2025, analysts had expected Meta's capital investments to come in around $51 billion this year.

Zuckerberg's comments suggest big tech isn't even close to being done with spending on AI development as the arms race continues into 2025. That's great news for a few important Meta suppliers: Nvidia (NVDA -0.14%), Broadcom (AVGO -1.48%), and Arista Networks (ANET -0.14%).

The building blocks of a data center

At the core of data centers focused on large language model training and inference are GPUs. In Zuckerberg's post, he said Meta will have 1.3 million GPUs by the end of the year. That's an increase from the 600,000 estimate Meta gave for the end of 2024.

Nvidia is the largest supplier of GPUs to Meta, and it's likely to stay that way in 2025. Nvidia's latest chips based on its Blackwell architecture promise 30 times the performance of its previous generation, with 25 times less cost and energy consumption. No competitor currently comes close to that level of performance out of the box like Nvidia's chips. And in a market where big tech companies are racing to stay ahead of one another, paying up for Nvidia's chips is the fastest path to stay ahead.

But Nvidia isn't the only company Meta relies on for AI chips. Meta designs its own silicon, working closely with Broadcom, to handle specific tasks related to Meta's AI development and deployment. For example, the ranking and recommendation models that power Facebook and Instagram's feeds, Stories, Reels, video, and more are built on Meta's own AI accelerator chips. These custom-built chips are faster and more power-efficient than general-purpose GPUs.

Meta is working to expand the scope of its own chips to include generative AI, and it'll likely continue taking steps toward that goal in 2025. That's great news for Broadcom, which is a key technology provider for Meta in that endeavor.

All those GPUs and AI accelerators need an efficient way to communicate with one another and make sure data gets from one place to another quickly. That requires Ethernet switches. Ethernet switches are like traffic controllers for data centers. They route data from one server to another and make sure there's no congestion on the network slowing everything down.

Meta partners with Arista Networks to create hardware and software solutions for its data centers. With plans to open a massive data center full of GPUs in 2025, Arista will see a strong step-up in orders from Meta as well.

Inside those Arista Ethernet switches are more Broadcom chips. Broadcom makes the logic chips that allow the hardware to route data efficiently. So, the company plays both a supporting role for Nvidia's chips while offering a competing product to some degree.

Are these stocks a buy?

Zuckerberg's announcement is certainly great news for the continued demand for AI infrastructure, such as that provided by Nvidia, Broadcom, and Arista Networks. All three should see strong revenue growth in 2025, which should translate into a nice bump in earnings for investors.

But just because a company is poised to grow in 2025 doesn't make its stock an automatic buy. Valuation still matters. All three of these stocks saw their prices climb significantly higher as excitement around the increased demand for their products permeated the market. As a result, their stocks became priced for perfection.

We saw the impact of that pricing recently following the realization of what High-Flyer's LLM DeepSeek has been working on and the potential long-term implications. While Nvidia, Broadcom, and Arista Networks could still show great financial results in 2025, DeepSeek's innovations call into question how long big tech will sustain its spending on hardware before focusing on making its software more efficient.

All three stocks come with considerable risks and uncertainty. Nvidia stock looks attractive based on forward earnings estimates for fiscal 2026 (ending next January), but the potential for declining market share and pressure on pricing power are long-term challenges.

Broadcom has a lot of upside as a designer of custom AI accelerators for Meta and other big tech companies, as well as creating essential chips for network switches. Its business is more diversified than Nvidia's, with some slower-growing segments outside AI-related chips. Still, it trades for a higher forward earnings multiple than Nvidia, based on Wall Street estimates.

Arista Networks is seeing great revenue growth, but its stock now trades for over 40 times forward earnings as of this writing. And that's after the impact of the DeepSeek news. Despite the strong demand for its hardware, the company isn't growing nearly fast enough to justify its current stock price.

While the comments from Zuckerberg may have provided some confidence in 2025 results for all three companies, the long-term questions and stock valuations make all three stocks risky to own. It may be worth it for some to add exposure to AI data center spending through these stocks, as long as investors remain mindful of the risks each poses and the constant changes happening in AI development.

6.title: Enormous tech company strikes deal to power Texas data centers
6.snippet: According to an agreement with Spanish-based Zelestra, four solar facilities will put 595 MW of energy into the ERCOT grid for Meta's data centers.
6.content:
A solar farm in Central Texas. Meta has struck a deal with a Spanish-based energy development company to put four facilities in Texas to help power its data centers. RoschetzkyIstockPhoto/Getty Images/iStockphoto

Meta, the owner of Facebook, Instagram, Threads and WhatsApp that may soon become a Texas company, struck a deal this week to get its Lone Star State data centers powered. The agreement with Spanish-based renewable energy company Zelestra calls for four solar projects, totalling 595 megawatts (MW), to be constructed in Texas.

Some project details including costs were not revealed in the announcement made Thursday. However, the four projects will bring additional solar power to the main Texas grid, which is maintained by the Energy Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT). The solar plants will be located in Henderson, Hopkins and Lamar counties, which are each east of the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex, and Lampasas County north of Austin.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

"We are excited to announce these solar projects with Zelestra," said Meta Head of Global Energy Urvi Parekh. "The renewable energy from these projects will support our data center operations, as well as our ongoing efforts to match our electricity usage with 100 percent clean and renewable energy."

Meta has struck a deal with a Spanish-based energy development company to power the tech company's data centers in Texas. NurPhoto/NurPhoto via Getty Images

On Friday, the Wall Street Journal reported that Meta has been in talks with Texas officials about potentially moving its address of incorporation from Delaware to Texas. Elon Musk's SpaceX very publicly moved its incorporation address from Delaware to Texas last year; after a First State judge struck down his multi-billion-dollar pay package, Musk told other executives he recommends they move "to another state as soon as possible."

But that isn't all Meta has done to inch closer to the Lone Star State. As the year kicked off, Meta announced it was moving its trust and safety teams from California to Texas and other U.S. locations. According to Meta founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg, the move to Republican-led states helps their case for increased neutrality.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

"As we work to promote free expression, I think that it will help us build trust to do this work in places where there's less concern about the bias of our teams," Zuckerberg said at the time.

Meta has several data centers sprinkled throughout the U.S. In Texas, it operates a $1.5 billion, 2.5 million-square-foot center in Fort Worth and an $800 million, approximately 900,000-square-foot facility in Temple. The Lone Star State is becoming a hotspot for data centers, where massive computer systems store everything from servers to network equipment, and from cloud-based to AI data. In October, SB Energy announced its 875-MW operation north of Austin to power Google's data centers were ready to go. Earlier this month, internet provider Gigabit Fiber announced a 540-MW data center and tech space south of Dallas.

Because these data centers are so large and house complex computer systems, they typically require a substantial amount of energy to power. The 595 MW of solar power created by Zelestra's plants to power Meta's facilities is enough to energize approximately 150,000 homes during peak demand.

8.title: Meta Platforms: Analyzing The Advertising Giant
8.snippet: I've been a shareholder of Meta Platforms since September of 2022, when I decided to invest, as I believed the company was undervalued and had a lot of...
8.content:
I’ve been a shareholder of Meta Platforms since September of 2022, when I decided to invest, as I believed the company was undervalued and had a lot of growth potential due to its exceptional organizational properties. I vividly remember seeing the company trading at a 60% below its all-time high at the time I bought my shares. As of this writing, my original investment is worth almost 5X.

Investors always say to buy businesses when they’re cheap. However, most of the time, when stock prices drop as much as Meta did in 2022 (75% from ATH at the lowest point) is usually for a fundamentally sound reason. In meta’s case, along a complex macroeconomic environment, was due to TikTok explosive growth, its revenue stagnation, and its significant spending on new projects such as the metaverse, whose returns were completely uncertain.

As depicted in the chart below, 2022 ended with revenue declining a bit more than $1B, capex increased by 70%, and net profit margin and free cash flow per share declined from 33.4% to 19.9%, and from 13.6 to 7, respectively. Fundamentally speaking, the company was going through a tough time, which resulted in the significant stock price decline. By the way, this is a great example that shows that stock prices ultimately track fundamentals.

Fundamentals

Stock Price

This times of uncertainty made most investors skeptical about the company’s growth potential and its management ability to allocate capital to new projects. What I saw, however, was an organization with exceptional organizational properties that was going through a short term crisis, and that sooner or later (in this case sooner) was going to recover. What happened to Meta in 2022, although not usual in exceptional organizations, happens to almost every organization that is trying to innovate and make the greatest products on earth. Amazon’s stock dropped by over 90% during the dot-com crash and Netflix dropped almost 75% in 2022, as they reported its first loss of subscribers in over a decade. You just have to take a look at where they are now.

The goal of this post is to understand Meta’s organizational properties, which were the reason why the company was able to 7X its value in 2 years after losing 75% of its value in one year. Furthermore, I’ll also analyse its fundamentals. These are the two main things I look for when investing into a company. The former can essentially guide us on how the company can evolve over the future, while the latter is a reflection of the former, and shows how the company has evolved since its IPO and what is its current situation.

Within organizational properties, the goal is to understand Meta’s culture, management, leadership, hierarchy and systems and policies. This, I believe, will give investors a solid overview of how the organization runs internally and how they think when operating it, which is ultimately the thesis of any investment. The KPIs found within the organizational properties will help investors determine whether they believe the organization is bound to grow over the coming decades or not.

Within fundamentals, the goal is to understand Meta’s business segments, MOAT and financials. Key KPIs found within the income statement, free cash flow statement and balance sheet, such as debt levels, profit margins, and return on investment capital, among others, will give a solid overview of how well the company is currently doing financially. At the end of the day, stock prices track free cash flow per share. If the company is not able to grow this metric, investors won't be able to make the type of return on investment they’re looking for. Although this alone won't tell investors how the company will evolve over time, it is essential to understand its growth potential.

Business Segments

Meta Platforms operates through two primary business segments, each contributing to its dominance in the digital ecosystem. While the company is primarily known for its social media platforms, its ambitions extend beyond traditional advertising, venturing into artificial intelligence, virtual reality, and other frontier technologies. Meta's business segments can be categorized into Family of Apps (FoA), and Reality Labs (RL), as depicted in the image below.

Segments Revenue

The Family of Apps segment includes Meta’s core social networking platforms: Facebook, Messenger, Instagram, Threads and WhatsApp. This division is the company’s primary revenue driver, generating, as of today, approximately 97% of Meta’s revenue through digital advertising. Meta’s ad ecosystem is powered by an advanced data-driven algorithm, leveraging artificial intelligence to deliver highly targeted ads across its platforms. Despite more regulations and growing competition, Meta’s advertising business is still one of the most profitable in the industry, thanks to its huge user base of over 3.35 billion daily active users across all platforms, as of Q4 2024.

Family of Apps

Additionally, within Family of Apps (FoA), Meta has been expanding into financial services and digital commerce, generating $519 million in revenue from payments and other growth initiatives such as Meta Pay, a payment processing system formerly known as Facebook Pay. This service allows users to send money, purchase goods, and make in-app transactions across Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp. I believe the company aims to create a seamless cross-platform payment system by integrating shopping experiences directly into its apps. While still a small fraction of its total revenue, this segment represents Meta’s ambition to diversify its income streams beyond digital advertising.

On the other hand, Reality Labs represents the high-cost, high-risk investments in future technologies. It is Meta’s long-term bet on the metaverse, augmented reality (AR), and virtual reality (VR). This division is responsible for hardware, including Meta Quest headsets, Ray-Ban smart glasses, and other AR/VR devices. They are expensive investments that, as of today, are recording multi-billion-dollar losses as Meta works to scale the technology and drive adoption. However, Zuckerberg remains committed to this vision.

Culture and Leadership

The ultimate thesis of any investment comes down to the culture and the people that work within the organization. Without the right group of individuals, no business can keep growing over decades, which is what I look for when investing into a business.

Mark Zuckerberg has created one of the greatest organizations precisely because he has been able to build a culture in which competent individuals have the freedom to innovate and iterate at a faster rate than their competitors. In fact, one of their mottos is to move fast. He, as the leader, wants individuals that work within Meta to learn as much as possible so that they end up building the greatest products on earth. Not only that, but he is also extremely client focused, which is also a trait of high quality leaders and management.

An interesting system that he has built within the organization is that there’s thousands of versions running of the apps, so that engineers can test new features by trial and error. By doing so, engineers can also see how the inputs affect the outputs, which include sharing, time spent, engagement, amount of friends that users have, amount of money that they make, … .

As he mentions in the following interview, made eleven years ago, this way of working is extremely empowering for engineers, as they can directly see the impact of their work without having to ask for approval from someone above them. In other words, Zuckerberg has created an organization that empowers engineers to build the best products and that lacks the bureaucracy that many other companies have, and which are responsible for not making them innovate and move fast enough.

Not only that, but he has also proved to be a fantastic capital allocator, which is one of the key traits that I look for in a leader when investing in a company. He has not only made some of the greatest acquisitions in business history, but has also proved that he understands the direction in which the world is going by investing a lot of capital into the required hardware to build the AI infrastructure that he believes will be essential to make the company grow over the future, while remaining as efficient as possible.

Regarding acquisitions, probably one of the most, if not the most remarkable one was the one he made in 2012, when he bought Instagram for $1B. Although the data is not publicly available, Instagram’s estimated revenue in 2024 was $71B, and analysts and industry experts have estimated Instagram’s current valuation to range between $250 billion and $300 billion based on its user base, advertising power, and role in Meta's ecosystem. That’s a 250X in terms of valuation in less than 15 years.

Another significant acquisition was Whatsapp, which he paid $19B in 2014. Although many believed that he paid a high price for it, it has shown to be a great one, as it now serves over 2 billion users globally. Although Meta has not been able to monetize Whatsapp in the same way it has done with instagram (its revenue is estimated to be $10b as of 2024), by owning whatsapp, they are able to collect more data, which is one of their primary goals and one of the reasons why the company is valued at approximately $100B.

Moreover, In 2023, Zuckerberg announced that the company was going to have a strong emphasis on efficiency going forward, meaning that those employees that were not efficient enough to the company would be terminated. In 2023, a year in which companies had to cut costs due to a complex macroeconomic environment, Meta cut almost 20,000 jobs and now, in 2025, they have announced that they will lay off around 5% of its workforce, or around 3,600 employees.

In the two charts above, you can see the evolution of the number of meta’s employees and its change over time. In the one below, you can see the revenue per employee in millions, which is a key metric that I take a look at when determining the efficiency of businesses. As you can see, there’s clearly a turning point in 2023, when meta decided to focus on efficiency. This reduction of employees who were not efficient for Meta’s standards translated into revenue per employee growing from 1.5 million at the end of 2022 to 2.3 million at the end of 2024. As the company becomes increasingly more operationally efficient due to technological advancements, I expect the two charts above to continue declining, while the one below continues to rise over time.

Lastly, Zuckerberg is also, in my opinion, the greatest example of how a leader is able to understand the market in which he is playing and adapt to new challenges, which are quite common in the fast evolving tech industry. A recent example that shows this is the recent announcement of its discontinuation of its third party fact checking program in the United states, which is an initiative to foster freedom of expression within its platforms, as Elon Musk is doing with X. He has taken this decision just after president elect Donald Trump has been reelected, which has expressed several times its support for freedom of speech.

I believe that he has realized that the woke culture that the US was experiencing over the last decade no longer entices citizens and that the world is slowly shifting towards a culture in which traditional values, freedom of speech and meritocracy are respected and valued again. Although it is unknown whether he has taken this decision because of the electoral change or because he actually supports it, it goes to show that he is extremely capable of identifying the ever evolving cultural shifts that take place in the globe almost immediately, and that he is consistently making decisions based on the best interest of his company.

AI Infrastructure

Zuckerberg is intentionally investing a lot of capital in AI infrastructure because he believes that the outcome of this significant investment not only will translate into a strong ROI but also lower the company’s operating expenses, which will help his goal of making his company as efficient and lean as possible. These are some words from Mark Zuckerberg, CEO, Q4 2024 conference call:

“These are all big investments -- especially the hundreds of billions of dollars that we will invest in AI infrastructure over the long term. I announced last week that we expect to bring online almost 1GW of capacity this year, and we're building a 2GW and potentially bigger AI datacenter that is so big that it’ll cover a significant part of Manhattan if it were placed there.”

However, he has been doing so in a different way compared to its competitors. Instead of just acquiring Nvidia's H100 GPUs chips, which are specifically built for training LLMs (large language models), he has recently been also acquiring more AMD's MI300 chips, which are more focused on inference. By doing so, he is betting that inference costs, which are the operating costs to run the AI models, will keep growing over time as the amount of users increases, while training costs, which are the initial costs to train models, will decline over time, as companies find ways to train models in a more efficient and cheap way.

This is exactly what DeepSeek might just have proved. If you’re not familiarized with this chinese AI startup, just a few day ago, on January 20, they released an AI model called DeepSeek-R1, which they say they have trained at a far lower cost than American companies such as Open AI or Perplexity have been able to do over the past years. The way in that they have achieved this is by employing reinforcement learning, which is a technique in which the model learns by trial and error to improve its behavior based on the incentives provided, instead of using the traditional process of fine tuning, in which you take a pre-trained machine learning model and adapt it to a specific task or dataset.

If true, this goes to show that Zuckerberg might be right and that LLMs training costs going forward might be reduced significantly without having to sacrifice quality on the outcome of models. Additionally, it would also mean that those companies which are part of the supply chain of designing and producing the hardware required to build the models, such as Nvidia, TSMC or ASML, will suffer the consequences, as companies will no longer need the amount of hardware that we all thought they were originally going to need.

By acquiring more AMD chips, and open sourcing Lama 4, Meta’s AI model, one can assess that Zuckerberg's strategic move is to let competitors, external developers and researchers experiment, innovate, and contribute to its advancement, so that Meta can then learn from these innovations or even adopt the best ideas. In fact, without Meta open sourcing its model, Deepseek would have not been able to build its DeepSeek-R1 model. In short, while others are focused on training the best models, Zuckerberg is focused on building the required infrastructure to then adopt all the innovations that competitors are developing by spending millions or even billions of dollars in training AI models. On the contrary to what everyone originally thought, LLMs might become commodities rather than assets.

Interestingly, while investing billions in Capex on Nvidia and AMD hardware, among others, Meta is also developing its own chips. The initiative began several years ago, in 2020, but it was not until 2023 that Meta introduced Meta Training and Inference Accelerator (MTIA), a custom-designed chip aimed at improving the efficiency of AI workloads across its platforms. As you can imagine, this chip is specifically tailored for Meta’s AI-driven applications, particularly in ranking and recommendation systems used in Meta’s apps. Unlike general-purpose GPUs, which are optimized for a broad range of AI tasks, MTIA is designed to handle Meta’s unique AI workloads more efficiently.

These are some words from Susan Li, CFO, Q4 2024 conference call:

“Finally, we’re pursuing cost efficiencies by deploying our custom MTIA silicon in areas where we can achieve a lower cost of compute by optimizing the chip to our unique workloads. In 2024 we started deploying MTIA to our ranking and recommendation inference workloads for ads and organic content. We expect to further ramp adoption of MTIA for these use cases throughout 7 2025 before extending our custom silicon efforts to training workloads for ranking and recommendations next year.”

One can only think that Meta is starting to develop its own chips because they want to stop fully relying on third party chip suppliers and start being self-sufficient. The reasons are quite obvious. The rising demand for hardware produced by NVIDIA and AMD has led to significantly higher prices and extended waiting times for their products. By developing in-house chips, Meta gains two things. First, they can design them for their specific needs, and second, they gain greater control over its AI infrastructure, ensuring that it can scale its machine learning and generative AI capabilities without bottlenecks caused by supply chain constraints or competition for high-performance GPUs.

Whether or not they will be able to build what companies such as NVIDIA or AMD have been building for decades is a topic for another day. What is crystal clear is that they want to stop fully relying on external chip providers, and that they aim to gradually transition towards a model where they can design and manufacture chips tailored specifically to their unique requirements.

MOAT

Although Meta is not an advertising monopoly, as there are other major players in the digital advertising landscape such as Google, Amazon, and even smaller platforms like TikTok and Snapchat, it undeniably operates as a social interaction monopoly. Meta's dominance stems from its unparalleled ability to centralize and facilitate human interaction through its platforms, which, as of today, collectively serve more than 3.35 billion people out of the 8.2 on a daily basis, representing approximately 40% of the total population.

It’s worth mentioning that approximately 2.6 billion people, or about 32% of the global population, don’t have access to internet connection. Therefore, if we just account for those people that have access to internet connection (5.6 billion), Meta’s apps are actually being used by a little over 57% of the connected population.

Although it is unrealistic to say that there will be a time where the entire population will have access to internet connection, it is realistic to say that the percentage of connected people is increasing at an exponential rate and will keep doing so due to technological advancements such as Starlink, which its satellite internet service lets people access the internet from anywhere in the world.

As of today, Meta is one of the companies with the strongest network effects. As more users join their apps, it becomes increasingly harder for competitors to build apps whose primary goal is to connect people among each other. Not only that, but Meta has created an ecosystem in which users and businesses have their apps integrated between each other, making it extremely hard for them to leave their apps. This centralization of communication gives Meta a unique position as a hub for social interaction in the digital age.

In addition, Meta's algorithms and data-driven insights significantly influence how people consume information, form opinions, and interact with content. Through personalized feeds and targeted recommendations, Meta shapes user experiences in ways that often reinforce its ecosystem, making it challenging for competitors to offer a similar level of integration and reach.

This near-monopoly on social interaction provides Meta with a steady stream of user data, fueling its advertising model and reinforcing its market position. While other platforms may compete in specific niches, TikTok in short-form video, LinkedIn in professional networking, or Reddit in community-driven forums, Meta’s ecosystem remains unmatched in its scope, making it a de facto monopoly for social connectivity in many parts of the world.

User Addiction

Many consider Meta to be tobacco 2.0. The comparison comes from the fact that, like previously mentioned, Meta’s algorithms are intentionally designed to make users addicted to its content. Their goal, like many other tech platforms, is to maximize user engagement and time spent on their platforms. This is a strategic decision tied to the company’s primary revenue model: advertising. The more time users spend on their platforms, the more ads they see, and the more data Meta collects to improve ad targeting, which results in revenue increase over time.

These are some of the most essential features responsible for making metas products so addictive:

Meta’s apps are designed to maximize user engagement through a combination of sophisticated algorithms and psychologically addictive mechanisms. Personalized content delivery is a cornerstone of this strategy. Meta's algorithms analyze vast amounts of user data, including likes, shares, comments, watch history, and the time spent viewing specific posts. By tailoring content to align with a user’s interests and behaviors, the platform ensures that users are consistently exposed to highly relevant and engaging material. This creates a feedback loop, where user interaction fuels further customization, making the experience increasingly compelling over time. In other words, the more you use their products, the more data Meta can analyze, and the better the algorithm becomes.

Another critical aspect of user retention is the deployment of dopamine loops. Features such as likes, reactions, comments, and notifications are specifically designed to trigger small bursts of dopamine, the brain’s reward chemical. The anticipation of social validation or the discovery of new information becomes a powerful motivator, keeping users coming back for more. This mechanism operates similarly to gambling, where the promise of a reward is irresistible, even if the timing and nature of that reward are unpredictable.

The infinite scrolling feature further reinforces this engagement. By removing natural stopping points, the design allows users to consume content endlessly, often resulting in losing track of time. Without clear cues to take a break, users are drawn into prolonged sessions, consuming far more content than they may have initially intended.

Finally, algorithmic prioritization of engagement plays a pivotal role in sustaining user interest. Meta’s algorithms are fine-tuned to highlight content that elicits strong emotional reactions, such as outrage, joy, or curiosity. Emotionally charged content is inherently more engaging, prompting users to spend longer periods interacting with the platform. This prioritization ensures that users remain emotionally invested, further deepening their reliance on the platform.

Although true, I strongly disagree with the original statement. While tobacco does not provide any type of benefit to any end consumer, Meta does. Let me explain. Within Meta’s apps, users have a very important decision to make: Either to be a consumer or a creator. As a consumer, individuals engage with content passively, scrolling through posts, watching videos, or reacting to others' creations. This mode of use can often lead to mindless consumption, with users spending hours on the platform without a clear purpose, potentially fostering dependency or wasting time. This is where Meta’s apps can resemble the addictive qualities of tobacco, offering dopamine hits without delivering substantial long-term benefits. However, as with any other thing in life, you, as the consumer, have the choice to make good use of Meta’s apps. Because of them, you can instantly communicate with family and friends globally, you have the opportunity to connect with new people, and you can learn basically anything you want by accessing the vast amount of information uploaded by other users. It can therefore have a positive impact in your life.

The story changes entirely for those who choose to be creators. Meta's apps empower users to create and share content, build businesses, educate others, and form communities. Entrepreneurs can sell products through Facebook Marketplace or Instagram Shops, small businesses can reach global audiences with targeted ads, and educators can spread knowledge through engaging content. These tools essentially enable creators to leverage the platform for either personal or business purposes. Many people have experienced their lives improve significantly because of Meta’s apps.

Ultimately, the difference lies in how the apps are used. While Meta provides the infrastructure, the choice to consume passively or produce actively rests with the individual. Unlike tobacco, which offers no pathway to growth or improvement, Meta's apps contain immense potential for those who want to use them productively.

Financials

“Our primary focus remains investing capital back into the business, with infrastructure and talent being our top priorities.” - Susan Li, CFO, Q4 2024 conference call.

Income Statement

Meta is one of the greatest examples of what I like to see in a company when investing. Their capital allocation philosophy is top notch. They have proved time and time and again that they are able to successfully allocate capital to the projects with the strongest ROI and their acquisitions over their trajectory have been nothing but outstanding.

As previously mentioned, most of Meta’s revenue comes from its main business segment, the advertising from its Family of Apps. In Q4 2024, it generated $46.8B in revenue, accounting for approximately 97% of its total revenue. This goes to show that although they are significantly investing into its reality labs business segment, as of today, Meta is an advertising company.

The company’s expenses are not distributed in the same way as its revenue. In Q4 2024, total expenses were $25B. Family of Apps incurred expenses totalling $19.0 billion, accounting for 76% of Meta's overall expenses, while Reality Labs reported expenses of $6.0 billion, accounting for 24% of total expenses for the quarter. Therefore, Family of Apps had an operating income of $28.3B, and Reality Labs had an operating loss of $5B.

Their business model allows them to have broad profit margins, which are one of the first financial metrics that I look at when analyzing a company. In my opinion, in Meta’s case, they are just getting started. The company is now focused on building the required infrastructure to be able to build the greatest products on earth, and that means a significant increase in Capex, which reduces profit margins. Having this in mind, Meta’s profit margin during the last six quarters have ranged from 30% to 45%, which is extraordinary.

Cash Flow Statement

In 2024, Meta has generated $54,072B in free cash flow, which after dividing by Meta’s $164,501B total revenue for the year gives a free cash flow margin of 32.9%, which means that for every dollar the business generates, it produces 32.9 cents in cash. This cash can be very beneficial as it can then be reinvested into the business or used for stock buybacks. The average free cash flow margin over the last four years is 28.44%, which goes to show that the company is actually highly efficient at converting revenue into actual cash.

Balance Sheet

The balance sheet is strong, ending Q4 2024 with total assets of $276,054B and total liabilities of $93,417B. It seems like liquidity issues are not a concern as the current ratio, which is current assets/current liabilities, is close to 3 (the higher this ratio the lower the probabilities of the company facing liquidity issues). Solvency issues won’t be a concern either, as the debt to assets ratio, which is the total debts/total assets is 0.33 (the lower this ratio, the lower the probabilities of the company facing solvency issues).

Furthermore, Meta’s cash and cash equivalents position is also strong, totalling almost $44B as of December 31, 2024. The company is also quite efficient at using its capital resources, as reflected by its ROIC (Return On Invested Capital) of 35.35%, which indicates that Meta generates a return of 35 cents for every dollar invested.

Final Thoughts

Meta is one of the greatest organizations I’ve come across as an investor. Its organizationals properties have been nothing but extraordinary since inception, and its fundamentals, although suffered a few times along the way, as of today, are fantastic.

The company’s culture, which is one of the key things that I look for when analyzing a company’s organizational properties, is top notch. This is mainly due to Zuckerberg’s leadership traits, which, along with the management team, goes to show the importance of people within an organization.

Additionally, the company is extremely focused on long term growth. Their significant investments in AI infrastructure prove that they are willing to sacrifice short-term gains in order to make even bigger long-term gains by creating the best products on earth. This is not an easy decision to make as a public company. What is crystal clear is that their goal is to operate as efficiently and leanly as possible, and this requires a significant amount of investments in the necessary technology, which is exactly what they’re doing.

Although I believe Meta is no longer an asymmetrical bet, I do believe that its exceptional organizational properties, such as its culture, leadership and systems, along its strong fundamentals, will be a catalyst for the company to keep growing over the coming decades. As long as this remains, I will keep holding my shares.

Hope I provided some value.

Talk soon,

Alfonso
